Award.AwardTitle: Affine Manifolds, Log Geometry, and Mirror Symmetry
Award.AbstractNarration:
M. Gross plans to study the geometry of mirror symmetry for Calabi-Yau manifolds. This will be done from the perspective of an algebro-geometric version of the Strominger-Yau-Zaslow conjecture introduced by M. Gross and B. Siebert. Associated to certain sorts of large complex structure limit degenerations of Calabi-Yau manifolds one can define an intersection complex, which is an affine manifold with singularities. Conversely, given an affine manifold with singularities, Gross and Siebert showed it is possible to build explicitly such a degeneration in terms of "tropical" data on the affine manifold with singularities. M. Gross plans to study applications of this construction, and in particular intends to work towards the goal of showing that this construction provides a geometric explanation for mirror symmetry. Ultimately, it will be shown that the same tropical structures determine both numbers of rational curves and period calculations on the two different sides of mirror symmetry.

The work proposed by M. Gross lies at the intersection of string theory and geometry. String theory replaces the traditional notion of the point particle with a small loop of string, moving through space-time.
To make string theory compatible with quantum mechanics, space-time must be ten-dimensional. Since space-time appears four-dimensional, one expects six of these dimensions to be a very small "curled up" geometric object.
These geometric objects are called Calabi-Yau manifolds. In the early 1990s, string theorists proposed a remarkable association between completely different Calabi-Yau manifolds: certain calculations extremely difficult to perform on one Calabi-Yau manifold could be completed by performing completely different, and much easier, calculations on a different Calabi-Yau manifold. This discovery was known as mirror symmetry.
Since this time, many geometers have been trying to understand the mathematics behind this miraculous observation. The work of M. Gross hopes to give mathematical insight and explanation for the phenomenon of mirror symmetry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
String theory has been one of the leading candidates for a theory unifying gravity with quantum field theory. While it has captured the public imagination, as yet it has not produced any experimentally verifiable predictions. On the other hand, string theory has made a number of astonishing predictions of a mathematical nature. These predictions can then be verifed mathematically.

One of the most interesting predictions is a phenomenon known as mirror symmetry. Roughly put, one of the basic predictions of string theory is that the universe should be ten-dimensional. While this seems obviously incorrect, one possible explanation is that six dimensions are extremely small. If one views a garden hose from a great distance away, it looks one-dimensional; one can only perceive its length. However, a small ant crawling on the
hose clearly sees two dimensions. Mirror symmetry is the observation that certain geometries of space-time yield the same physics as other geometries of space-time. In the example of the garden hose, string theory says that the physics of  a space-time modelled on a garden hose of radius r is the same as that modelled on a garden hose of radius 1/r. In other words, physics on a very thin garden hose is the same as physics on a very fat garden hose.

This phenomenon is most interesting when the very small dimensions form what is known as a six-dimensional Calabi-Yau manifold. These are extremely complicated spaces which mathematicians have studied for some time, and there are large numbers of unanswered questions about them. In 1991, motivated by initial string-theoretic observations, Candelas, de la Ossa, Greene and Parkes performed a remarkable calculation, predicting that certain numbers which were famously difficult to compute on one of these manifolds could be calculated via much simpler calculations on its "mirror". The numbers which are difficult to calculate are the numbers of spheres which one can find inside the Calabi-Yau manifold. These numbers are known as Gromov-Witten invariants.

These predictions have led to 20 years of investigations by a large number of mathematicians. These efforts have led to some very deep mathematics, and the search for an underlying explanation for mirror symmetry continues.

The work supported by this NSF grant has made significant contributions to this understanding. In joint work with B. Siebert, the PI has continued his program which is leading to a satisfactory explanation for the mysteries
of mirror symmetry. In this program, one finds that the two sides of mirror symmetry, seemingly very different in nature, are in fact controlled by a common geometry, called tropical geometry. (The word "tropical" honors
the Brazilian origins of aspects of the subject.) Tropical geometry is very combinatorial in nature. The spheres mentioned above are replaced by stick figures, collections of straight lines meeting up in precisely prescribed ways.

This work has led to a number of articles published by the PI and his collaborators. In joint work with Pandharipande and Siebert, he demonstrated that a key aspect of mirror symmetry can be explained using tropical
geometry. In another paper, the PI demonstrated that these ideas could be used to give a complete explanation for mirror symmetry in a relatively simple case, at the same time giving new formulas in tropical geometry. In joint work with Siebert, he developed a new counting theory, known as log Gromov-Witten theory, which should serve as a foundation for connecting many Gromov-Witten problems with tropical geometry.
